story: Barry Smith made headlines for ordering pupils to walk in single file to lessons, be asleep at .pm and up by .am every day.He also warned pupils that they would be given a bucket to throw up inthey felt ill in class to cut down on them feigning sickness to get out of lessons.His crackdown led to him being labelled Britain’s toughest headteacher in  after he took over a failing high school and relaunched it as Great Yarmouth Charter Academy, Norfolk.While he was praised by many parents, his appointment led to a backlash from others who accused him of “Army-like” behaviour and claimed that some of their children were left scared about going to school.But the education newspaper Schools Week has reported that Mr Smith has not been in charge of day-to-day activities at the -pupil school since early December.Sources told the publication that he was “moved out of the school following an incident involving the restraint of a pupil.”The Inspiration Trust which runs  primary and secondary schools and a sixth form college in Norfolk and Suffolk refused to comment on the reasons behind Mr Smith’s exit, but insisted he had not been suspended.A spokesperson said for the trust said: “Barry Smith has not been suspended. title: coronavirus spread chinese new year
story: At least nine people have died while  victims have been infected, mainly in Wuhan which is the epicentre of the outbreak.And with confirmed cases in Thailand, Japan and South Korea there are concerns that the upcoming Lunar New Year could spark a global pandemic.In fact, today it has been reported that the first case in the United States will be announced, according to federal sources.This Saturday marks the first day of the country’s New Year celebrations which is known as the largest annual human migration in the world.”Hundreds of millions of Chinese people willhome via planes, trains, ferries and by car – sparking mass movement within China as well as from abroad.According to the Washington Post, the holiday will result in an astonishing three billion trips.Officials confirmed this week that coronavirus - which causes pneumonia - can be passed from person to person.This has sparked fears that people infected could become a “super-spreaders” – someone who transmits the virus to a greater number of people than the average victim.The SARS virus in -, which also began in China and killed , spread into dferent countries due to a combination of a few super-spreaders and international travel.The climbing death toll comes amid reports the -nCoV strain has spread to other countries and major cities including Beijing, Shanghai and southern Guangdong province.Taiwan is the latest country to confirm a case of the lethal SARS-like virus - after Australian officials said a man is being tested amid fears he picked up the bug in China.Leading expert, Dr Jeremy Farrar, director of the Wellcome Trust, said that marks a serious sht change in the outbreak.This is extremely concerning, he warned. Person to person transmission has been confirmed and, as expected, we are seeing rapidly increasing case numbers across China, and in more countries, with health care workers infected.He praised the speed at which the virus has been identied, and the strong global coordination from the WHO, but warned more is to come from this outbreak.With travel being a huge part of the fast approaching Chinese New Year, it is right that concern levels are at the highest level, he added.A major concern is the range of symptoms this virus is causing.It is clear some people are being affected and are infectious while experiencing only very mild symptoms at or possibly no symptoms at all .This may be masking the true numbers infected and the extent of person to person transmission. It is a matter of urgency to work this out.Speaking on LBC today, leading virologist Professor John Oxford, from Queen Mary College, said he was quaking in my shoes at the potential for spread over the holidays.He said: None of us have faced a new virus with so many people in a community travelling around.Thats whats going to happen in China at the end of the week.Once they are close together in taxis or small rooms, then there may be a problem.The only way to stop it is physical cleaning and social distance - keeping away from people.The WHO announced it will hold an Emergency Committee meeting in Geneva tomorrow, to determinethe outbreak should be classed as a global crisis.While Chinese authorities have confirmed more than  cases, another  people are suspected ill with the new strain and around , more are under observation.Fteen healthcare professionals are among those infected.However, experts at Imperial College London predict the true number of cases could be far greater - with estimates closer to ,.WHOs regional director for the western Pacic, Takeshi Kasai, said: Information about newly reported infections suggest there may now be sustained human-to-human transmission.The mayor of Wuhan confirmed the latest deaths today, an -year-old man from the city, which is home to more than  million people.A -year-old man, known only as Li, and a woman, , known as Yin were also confirmed to have died from multiple organ failure.In Taiwan today, an epidemic response command centre has been set up with more than , beds prepared in isolation wards in case the virus spreads further.There, health officials confirmed a woman, thought to be in her s, had caught the new strain.She is currently in hospital and receiving treatment, according to local media reports.So far, the WHO has not advised travel or trade restrictions but could put such measures in place at tomorrows emergency meeting.WHO chiefs are set to considerthis outbreak should be declared a global emergency like the  Ebola outbreak in West Africa, the current outbreak in Congo and the Zika outbreak in Central America in .While NHS chiefs have urged doctors in the UK to be alert to signs of the killer virus, they said today the threat to Brits is low.The origin of the virus is not get known, but experts say the most likely source is an animal.Chinese officials have linked the outbreak last month to a seafood market in the city of Wuhan - where more than  cases have been confirmed.The new strain belongs to a large family of viruses that cause illnesses ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndromeand Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome .The common early signs of infection include fever, cough, shortness of breath and breathing dficulties, according to WHO.In more severe cases, it can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death.In Australia, border forces have been ordered to ensure all sick passengers are assessed by a trained Biosecurity officer on arrival.Chief health officer Brendan Murphy said the risk was low but added the three daily flights from Wuhan will be met by medics in response to the rapidly emerging situation.State health officials in New South Wales are distributing pamphlets in English and Chinese to all passengers arriving from Wuhan describing the symptoms.The crackdown comes as it was revealed the virus was feared to have reached Australia after a man was tested for the killer mystery bug.The man, from Brisbane, was displaying symptoms of the fatal coronavirus after ing from a family holiday and has been placed in quarantine.The US has also started screening passengers on flights from Wuhan arriving at John F. Kennedy International Airport, San Francisco International Airport and Los Angeles International airport.Other international airports are also screening passengers for the mysterious SARS-like disease after it was revealed it had jumped China’s borders.A video has been shared widely on Twitter showing people on a domestic flight out of the central Chinese city of Wuhan having their temperature taken one-by-one by people in protective suits.A Brit on holiday in Thailand is feared to be the first western victim of the illness.Ash Shorley, , was rushed to hospital after the bug infected both lungs while he was on Koh Phi Phi island in Thailand.The outbreak has caused alarm because of its connection to Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome , which killed nearly  people across mainland China and Hong Kong in -.The virus attacks the respiratory system, causing lung lesions.Symptoms include a runny nose, headache, cough and fever, shortness of breath, chills and body aches.It is incredibly contagious and is spread through contact with anything the virus is on as well as infected breath, coughs or sneezes.Symptoms include a runny nose, headache, cough and fever, shortness of breath, chills and body aches.In most cases, you wont know whether you have a coronavirus or a dferent cold-causing virus, such as rhinovirus.Buta coronavirus infection spreads to the lower respiratory tract , it can cause pneumonia, especially in older people, people with heart disease or people with weakened immune systems.There is no vaccine for coronavirus.In  an outbreak of a similar virus, SARS, infected more than , people in  countries before it was brought under control, killing  of those worldwide.Coronaviruses cause diseases ranging from the common cold to more severe ones such as SARS.The Chinese government initially tried to conceal the severity of that epidemic but its cover-up was exposed by a high-ranking physician.Initial symptoms of the novel coronavirus include fever, cough, tightness of the chest and shortness of breath, and those seriously ill developed pneumonia.At least half a dozen Asian countries and three US airports have started screening incoming airline passengers from central China.Chinese President Xi Jinping said it was “extremely crucial” to take every possible measure to combat the disease that has infected at least  people in the country.He said: The recent outbreak of novel coronavirus pneumonia in Wuhan and other places must be taken seriously“Party committees, governments and relevant departments at all levels should put people’s title: elephant man joseph merrick freak show poverty
story: That’s how most of us think of Joseph Merrick — wrongly called John in the  David Lynch film — but nothing could be further from the truth.Despite his lumpy and malformed features, the real Merrick escaped a le of poverty to make his own money before enchanting the wealthy upper classes, even making friends with the Queen’s great-grandmother.But in his home town, Leicester, there is nothing to celebrate the le of this trailblazer for people with disabilities. That’s why I have been campaigning for a statue to be erected in his honour.But shockingly, I’ve faced strong opposition to a Merrick memorial. I’ve had abuse over social media, with cruel protesters mocking his disability by saying: “Leicester’s ugly enough.”I’ve even been called a “vampire showman” — a reference to freak show bosses who people mistakenly believe made his le a misery.Behind this stereotype, the true story of the Elephant Man is a tale of empowerment and inspiration. He was nothing like the film suggests, but rather an independent disabled man who was ahead of his time.In , aged  and impoverished, he checked himself into the Leicester workhouse, a dire institution where the destitute were given food, shelter and work.Despite his disability, for four years Merrick would have probably been put to work grinding stone or crushing bones.He was faced with a decision — whether to stay there and die or go out and live his le. He decided he would try to make his name and fortune by appearing in a novelty show.Victorians loved the weird and dferent and would pay to see a bearded lady or a tattooed man at one of these shows. But importantly, it was a way for people who were dferent to earn good money and avoid the workhouse.So Merrick wrote to music hall manager Sam Torr, asking him to be his agent, just like in the  film The Greatest Showman.Torr then arranged Merrick’s release from the workhouse and he was soon touring around clubs in the East Midlands.Then when he ran out of local audiences he moved to London, where he met his next agent, Tom Norman — a distant cousin of mine.They set up the Elephant Man show on Whitechapel Road, and for the two weeks they worked together and were more like business partners than owner and slave.In the  film, Tom Norman is portrayed as Mr Bytes, an old drunk who beats Merrick. Norman was actually young, and a member of the Temperance movement, which campaigned against drunkenness, so certainly not a boozy old man.For a fee, Norman would tell crowds a myth of how, at his birth, Merrick’s mother was stamped on by an elephant, resulting in a half-man, half- elephant creature.He would pull back a curtain to reveal Merrick, leaving audiences gawping in amazement. Enterprising Merrick wrote a short pamplet of his le story, which was sold at the show, and he would keep these earnings for himself.In the film we see Merrick’s mother Mary Jane screaming in terror while being trampled by elephants. But according to Merrick himself, his disability did not begin to show until he was five.He lived a normal childhood, going to school and learning to read and write. Mary Jane, a Sunday school teacher, died from unknown causes when he was just , and his father — also Joseph — soon remarried.By then young Joseph was keen to go out and start earning a living. He initially worked in a cigar factory before getting a peddler’s licence to hawk bobbins and gloves around Leicester.He later saidhe didn’t make enough money, his father and stepmother would not feed him. While this sounds like child abuse to us, the Victorians firmly believed in “spare the rod and spoil the child” so this would have been seen as normal.The cause of Merrick’s disability is still open to debate but the most popular diagnosis is proteus syndrome, a rare condition characterised by overgrowth of the bones and skin.A doctor has even suggested that his condition is unique — and should be named Merrick’s syndrome after its lone sufferer.It is impossible to test Merrick’s DNA to identy the illness, as when he died, his flesh was stripped from his bones, which were bleached twice, while hairs taken from his clothes have failed to produce any DNA results.In his day he was a medical curiosity and doctors did try to study him. A surgeon, Frederick Treves, sought out Merrick and asked him to come to the London Hospital to be studied by doctors.At first Merrick agreed, yet after three or four visits he refused to go back, saying he felt like he was in a cattle market.Treves was furious and a week later police shut down Merrick and Norman’s show as a public nuisance. Whether Treves had a hand in it is impossible to say.Undeterred and wealthy from his show with Norman, Merrick then spent three months with a travelling circus in Northamptonshire.While travelling, he began to wear a hood and cape so he could walk the streets without getting jeered or followed. His real ambition was to entertain audiences in Europe, so he advertised in the papers for a new manager who could take him to the Continent.Details of what happened abroad are vague but Merrick seems to have been robbed and abandoned by his new management, leaving him in Brussels without a penny to his name.He somehow travelled back to London, where he found Dr Treves, who agreed to let him stay at the London Hospital.His care would be funded by wealthy benefactors — but there would have been an expectation that Merrick would let doctors examine him.One, Dr Wilfred Granville, wrote in his memoirs that Merrick would look at specimens in the hospital and ponder what his body parts would look like in a bottle. It was clear he knew his fate.But there is no reason to believe Merrick was unhappy in the hospital, in fact he seems to have enjoyed himself.While the Queen’s great-grandmother Princess Alexandra was opening a nurses’ wing in the hospital, she visited Merrick and shook his hand.They became firm friends and she would often visit and write him letters. In turn, Merrick made her a cardboard model of a German cathedral. Her husband Prince Edward, the future King, even sent food and drink packages to Merrick.As a result of this friendship it became fashionable for the upper classes to visit Merrick and give him signed pictures and trinkets.Aristocrat Lady Louisa Knightley invited him to holiday at the grand Fawsley Hall in Northamptonshire, where he stayed three times, enjoying walking freely in the estate’s grounds without fear of being ridiculed.But he never forgot Tom Norman. A porter once overheard Merrick asking when he could visit his old friend. But when Tom visited the hospital he was refused entry and the pair never saw each other again.Many people believe Merrick died by taking his own le. He was unable to sleep on his back as the sheer weight of his head could dislocate his neck, so instead he was forced to sleep with his head against his knees.In the film a desperate Merrick — played by Oscar-nominated John Hurt — is shown removing the cushions which helped him to sit up straight while sleeping, insinuating that he killed himself.But while he did die tragically young at , the evidence points to his death being accidental. He was found in the afternoon — not at night — lying across his bed ashe had slipped and was trying to get up.His inquest found he had died from a dislocated neck but we can’t trust the science of the time. Merrick’s death could have been caused by a stroke or seizure, but it is a mystery we will never solve.While his skeleton is kept at the Royal London Hospital, last May I found the unmarked grave of some of his flesh in the City of London Cemetery and Crematorium in Ilford.It made worldwide news and I was astounded by the reaction to my discovery. So many people were interested in his story.This is what led me to my quest to get Merrick recognised for the great man he was, with a statue in Leicester city centre.I want people to take off their blinkers, see what he really did with his le and realise he was not just the freak show casualty who was portrayed in the Elephant Man film.And to those who complain his statue would be “ugly” — take a lesson from Merrick’s le to see what’s on the inside, not just the outside.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: french uni textbook 9 11 cia theory
story: The university textbook, titled History of the th Century in Flash Cards, was printed in November and contained the baseless conspiracy theory.The disturbing claim, printed on page , quickly went viral on social media after it was spotted by the daughter of a teacher who bought it.While discussing the creation of jihadi group al-Qaeda, the book says: “This global event - no doubt orchestrated by the CIAto impose American influence on the Middle East - hit the symbols of American power on its own territory.On September , , hijacked planes crashed into the World Trade Centre buildings in New York and the Pentagon building in Washington DC killing nearly , innocent people.But despite Islamic terror cult al-Qaeda, led by the evil Osama Bin Laden, claiming responsibility for the attack – sick conspiracy theories claiming the assault was an “inside job” have gained traction online.The French textbook, aimed at undergraduates, was written by Jean-Pierre Rocher, a teacher of history and geography.Publisher Ellipses said the author wanted to delete the claim and that the a correction would be added online and to any books published in the future.On its website, the firm issued an apology.It said: This phrase which echoes conspiracy theories devoid of any factual basis should never have been used in this work.“It doesnt reflect the editorial position either of Ellipses publications or the author.”The wild claim in the book began being shared online by a group of schoolteachers – after one of their daughters had spotted it.Bruno Modica, head of an education Facebook group where the claim was originally discussed, told Le Monde: It blew up very quickly.He continued: There were  comments. This inserted clause of his conveys a conspiracy theory you can hear in our classrooms, from some pupils mouths - but to find it written by a teacher and in this type of publication is unacceptable.The story was then picked by website Conspiracy Watch which pointed out that the book was aimed at a young demographic who are more likely to believe the debunked claims.It highlighted an Ifop poll from December  which found that  per cent of people aged under  believe the US government were involved in the attacks.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ousted grammy boss says votes are rigged by boys club in explosive document
story: A discrimination complaint filed by the former Chief Executive Officer and President of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences details how after , members vote on each category, a small, largely-male committee narrows down the field as they see fit.To make matters worse, the Board is permitted to simply add in artists for nominations who did not even make the initial -artist list, reads the filing submitted by Deborahs lawyer Jeannie Christensen of Wigdor LLP.Naturally, the members of the Board and the secret committees chose artists with whom they have personal or business relationships. This year,  artists that were not selected by the membership were added to the possible nomination list.The filing goes on to claim that in some cases, an eligible artist will even be on the committee that is selecting their category.As a result, one artist who initially ranked  out of  in the  Song of the Year category ended up with a nomination. This artist was actually permitted to sit on the Song of the Year nomination committee, reads the filing.Incredibly, this artist is also represented by a member of the Board.Deborah does not name that nominee, but she does identy two of the artists who were impacted by this move.As a result of the foregoing, it is not surprising that many high caliber artists who could have taken home the award in a specic category, have, at times, not been nominated at all, states the complaint.For instance, Ed Sheeran and Ariana Grande, who had been voted for by the membership, missed out on nominations in the  Song of the Year category in part because the aforementioned artist who ranked  out of  was nominated instead.Ariana seemed to be responding to this on Tuesday evening when she tweeted: u seen it.This happened in other categories too claims Deborah, who cites one other example in her filing.Similarly, in the “secret committee” for Best Jazz Vocals, artists that were up for an award in that category also participated in the nomination voting process, says the filing.Ms. Dugan actually learned about this from a Grammy Award winning artist who was also a committee member , who complained about improprieties and conflicts of interest within the nomination process.In other instances, Deborah claims that the committees just pick who they personally want to see on the show.The purpose of the nomination review committees is, ostensibly, to narrow the  potential nominationsdown to the five to eightmost deserving artists prior to resubmitting the final list to the voting members of the Academy, explains Deborah.However, the Board uses these committees as an opportunity to push forward artists with whom they have relationships. Indeed, it is not unusual for artists who have relationships with Board members and who ranked at the bottom of the initial -artist list to end up receiving nominations.It goes on to claim: The Board also manipulates the nominations process to ensure that certain songs or albums are nominated when the producer of the Grammyswants a particular song performed during the show.Dugan was put on leave last week following an allegation of misconduct by a senior leader at the organization.The Recording Academy then announced that Dugan had been “abusive” and created a “toxic and intolerable” work environment, an accusation that Dugan dismissed through her attorney.She is now seeking  million from the not-for profit organization.The Academy meanwhile said in response to the filing: Our loyalty will always be to the , members of the Recording Academy. We regret that music’s biggest night is being stolen from them by Ms. Dugan’s actions, and we are working to resolve the matter as quickly as possible.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: london off limits ambitious brits outside report
story: Hopes of moving there to do well are dashed by the sky-high cost of living.The findings will pile pressure on PM Boris Johnson to keep his promise to “level up” the country and tackle social inequality.Moving to London to become a professional “is largely the preserve of those from a privileged background”, says the report commissioned by the Sutton Trust educational charity.Sir Peter Lampl, founder and chairman of the Sutton Trust, said: “The Dick Whittington vision of moving to the capital to move up in the world is largely a myth.“Those that benefit most from opportunities in London were either born there or are the economically privileged from other parts of the country.“London is essentially off-limits to ambitious people from poorer backgrounds who grow up outside the capital.“That means that boosting London is not going to have much impact on making things fairer for anyone other than those already living there.”Researchers said the sky high cost of living in London and the growing number of unpaid internships are locking Brits out of the capital.The report by the London School of Economics also says a growing number of unpaid internships adds to the problem.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: At least nine people have died while  victims have been infected by the virus so far, with fears it could become global.Public Health England is expected to upgrade the risk to the UK from very low to low today.And as part of the increasingly stringent measures, it is expected Health Secretary Matt Hancock will put introduce port measures that will include:Dr Nick Phin, Public Health England deputy director, said: We have issued advice to the NHS and are keeping the situation under constant review.People travelling to Wuhan should maintain good hand, respiratory and personal hygiene and should avoid visiting animal and bird markets or people who are ill with respiratory symptoms.Iniduals should seek medical attentionthey develop respiratory symptoms within  days of visiting Wuhan, either in China or on theirto the UK, informing their health service prior to their attendance about their recent travel to the city.The outbreak of coronavirus is believed to have started in a market in Wuhan, China, in December - which is connected to London by three direct flights per week.The first case of the mystery illness in the US is set to be announced later today, federal sources said.The American patient was hospitalised for pneumonia last week and had recently travelled to Wuhan, China where the respiratory disease was first spotted.The virus could be declared a global health crisis after cases of the mystery bug previously quadrupled in just four days.And an expert warned the deadly new virus is one of the biggest global health threats. Scientists are frantically working on a vaccine to stop the spread of Wuhancoronavirus - but say it could be more than a year before its available.HOW is it spread  Coronaviruses are transmitted between animals and people. story: The Duchess of Sussex was pictured beaming as she headed to Mayhew - announcing the visit the same day Kate Middleton launched a whistlestop tour to promote a major early childhood project.Mayhew, in Kensal Green, North West London, is one of Meghans patronages that she will continue to support despite stepping down from the Royal Family.The photos were shared as Kate prepares for a whistlestop tour through the UK today, while Meghans father Thomas revealed fears in a candid interview the next time he would see his daughter was at his own funeral.And the visit comes after the former “Suits” star, , was spotted happily walking her own dogs with baby Archie in a wooded area of Vancouver Island, Canada.The dogs, a beagle named Guy and a black Labrador named Oz, were being watched by two royal protection officers from a distance as the happy family trotted along what looked like a trail.But despite relocating from the UK, the duchess threw her support behind her patronage this morning as the couples Instagram account shared photos of her patting a dog and meeting workers.Writing on Instagram, Sussex Royal said: Earlier this month, The Duchess of Sussex popped in to see the amazing people at Mayhew to hear about the incredible progress made throughout the festive period.The Duchess of Sussex, having been proud patron of Mayhew since January  and long understanding the connection between animal and community welfare, applauds the people at Mayhew for the vital work that they do every day.From cats and dogs who have found new homes to animal welfare cases handled in the community - @TheMayhew believes in the power of togetherness and the special bond between humans and animals.The last few posts on SussexRoyal appear to reassure the couples charities they arent abandoning them, despite stepping down from their roles as royalty.Harry and Meghan will no longer use their HRH titles under the change, while they will also pay pay the £.m of taxpayer money spent on refurbishing their Frogmore Cottage home. title: fog mist difference
story: But what exactly is it  Not many people actually know how fog is formed and how it dfers from mist.Fog is like a low-level cloud that originates from a local body of water - such as a lake, marsh or the sea.It dfers from regular clouds because it contains water droplets from a number of dferent sources.When water vapour in the air condenses into tiny droplets of liquid water, they stay suspended in the air and fog is formed.Fog contains up to .ml of water per cubic metre.If you were to fill an Olympic sized swimming pool with fog and then somehow condense it, you would be left with around . litres of water - just over  pints.The foggiest place in the world is an area of the Atlantic Ocean called Grand Banks off the coast of Newfoundland, Canada.The area forms the meeting place of the cold Labrador Current from the north and the much warmer Gulf Stream from the south.This creates over  days of fog every year.Fog warnings are often issued when driving conditions are dficult and dangerous.Fogs are generally named after the physical process that takes place to produce them.The main types of fog are as follows:This type of fog usually appears in the winter and is aided by clear skies and calm weather.The cooling of land overnight by thermal radiation cools the air close to the surface.This reduces the ability of the air to hold moisture and allows condensation and fog to occur.Radiation fogs usually disappear as the ground warms after sunrise.Freezing fog is made up of supercooled water droplets which remain liquid even though the temperature is below freezing point.One of the characteristics of freezing fog is that rime - a frost formed on cold objects made-up of feathery crystals - is deposited on the windward side of surfaces such as lampposts, pylons and transmitting masts.Valley fog forms where cold dense air settles into the lower parts of the valley condensing and forming fog.It is usually a result of warm air passing over the valley.It can last for several days during calm conditions in winter.This type of fog occurs when most air passes over a cool surface and is cooled.A common example of this is when a warm front passes over an area with snow cover.It is also common at sea when moist tropical air moves over cooler waters.If the wind blows in the right direction then sea fog can become transported over coastal land areas.Upslope fog or hill fog forms when winds blow air up a slope.The air cools as it rises and allows moisture in it to condense.This type of fog is caused by cold air passing over warmer water or moist land.It often causes freezing fog and sometimes frost.When warm water evaporates into the low air this type of fog occurs.The only dference between mist and fog is visibility.It is called fog when visibility is km or less and called mist when visibility remains above km.In driving terms it tends to be referred to as fog when visibility is m or less.According to the Highway Code, you have to use headlights when visibility is seriously reduced - generally defined as less than  metres .The AA recommends you take your time, keep a greater distance between you and the car in front and keep your front and rear fog lights on.You should be aware of how to operate your fog lights, and take care not to rely too much on automatic lighting.If you get to a junction and you cant see properly due to fog, stop and roll your windows down to listen to traffic.Fog is responsible for a rare weather phenomenon called a fog dome.The white bulbs are caused by a source of heat close to the ground that forces fog to lt away into a dome as warm air rises like a hot air balloon.Fog also has its own rainbows called a fog bow, which look like a normal rainbow but are just plain white.They are made up of tiny water droplets that are so small, they white-wash the fog bow.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bob mazzer amazing photos history britain
story: Captured by renowned London-born photographer Bob Mazzer, the new self-titled collection features a series of fascinating timeless stills that he started taking when he was going through a happy hippie phase during the s.Gted his first camera at , the famous photojournalist — best known for his illustrious career at Time Out — snapped his best work taken throughout the country since the s as well as a stint capturing the local faces by the seaside in Hastings and St Leonards, East Sussex.Candid shots of the streets of London also feature as do timeless stills of the London Underground ⁠— his signature work.For most people, the s are a period synonymous with a poor economy, high inflation, employment struggles and strikes, typied by the Winter of Discontent.On the other hand, s are seen as the decade of glamour and razzmatazz and, most memorably, the decade of Margaret Thatcher and the decline of the unions and the miners strike.The s saw the explosion of Britpop, Friends and the internet, book-ended with Tony Blairs  election victory and Mr Mazzers photos chart, the changing face of the nation.His nostalgic images, which feature in a book released later this month, feature kids trick or treating, sunburned holidaymakers, men and women flirting and students spacing out on the grass.The pictures are an enlightening insight into everyday le in Britain during a period plentul in radical change.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Fascinating photos show some of Second World Wars deadliest snipers in actionStories about Second World Wars sharp shooters include details about Lyudmila Pavlichenko, who was nicknamed Lady Death, and are featured in new book The Sniper Anthology, Snipers of the Second World WarShareCommentsByMartin Fricker:,  JAN NewsSoviet snipers on the Karelian Front during the Continuation War against Finland These remarkable photos show Second World War’s deadliest snipers in action.They include shots of Lyudmila Pavlichenko, who had more than  confirmed kills.Nicknamed "Lady Death", she was the most successful female sniper in history, became a Red Army poster-child and toured the US, Canada and Britain after the war.And other photos show ft ins Finnish sniper Simo Häyhä, nicknamed "White Death", who killed more than  men in just two years.He was able to camouflage himself with ease, using his skiing and moose hunting background to stalk enemy fighters.The amazing stories are documented in new book The Sniper Anthology, Snipers of the Second World War.Hesketh Vernon Prichards sniping during First World War influenced techniques for Second World War  of And during Second World War, a US Army sniper aims the Springfield Model -A rle  of Russian snipers meanwhile move slowly along a river bank  of Snipers of the Russian nd Army pose after being decorated in this snap  of A squad of American infantry try to locate a German sniper using a helmet to lure his shot  of Lyudmila Pavlichenko was the most successful Russian female sniper of the Second World War  of And Simo Haumlyhauml shows his wounds after he was hit in his lower left jaw with an explosive bullet  of Yelizaveta Miranova, another deadly Russian female sniper, was part of th Red Banner Marine Corps Brigade  of The Sniper Anthology, Snipers of the Second World War is out now  of More OnWorld War CommentsShow more comments

title: ex military chiefs launch outspoken
story: NewsEx-military chiefs launch outspoken attack on state of Royal Navy warshipsA former Chief of the Defence Staff and former First Sea Lord used a House of Lords debate to issue fresh warnings over the Navys destroyers and timetable for replacing frigatesShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsHMS Defender is one of the Type  destroyers which suffer from engine trouble " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo retired military chiefs tore into the Government last night over the “anorexic” state of the Royal Navy and its warships. Former Chief of the Defence Staff, Admiral Lord Boyce, and ex-head of the Navy, Lord West, delivered scathing verdicts on the Senior Service during a House of Lords debate. The UK has just six destroyers and  frigates - with more than a third stuck in dock at any one time. The former naval top brass issued the latest warnings about the Type , Daring-class destroyers, which cost £billion each and have been plagued by engine trouble.  They also voiced fears about the rate at which ageing Type , Duke-class frigates are being replaced by Type , City-class global combat ships. Speaking at Westminster, Lord Boyce said: “Our number of frigates and destroyers are anorexic, and this has been exacerbated by the Type  problem. “We embarked upon an eight-ship, Type  frigate building programme in , but the first ship, Glasgow, won’t be commissioned until . “Thereafter, a ship appears after every two years.”  The timetable was “completely unacceptable and is a black mark against the Government and our shipbuilding industry”, he stormed. Pressing the Government on the engine problems faced by the Type  vessels, Lord West hit out at “an appalling state of affairs”. He told peers: “We have six anti-air warfare ships, we knew eight years ago that they had a problem - that sometimes there would be a total lack of power, which would suddenly happen unexpectedly.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMillions of womenaposs state pension age rises are set to be fought in the Court of Appeal after campaigners won permission for a new hearing.Women lost a landmark High Court battle on all grounds in October against rises to their pension age - which they say left many penniless and retirements ruined.But the Back to  group now says it has now won permission to contest the ruling in the Court of Appeal. The case now has a new urgency as one of the two women making the claim, -year-old Julie Delve, is being treated for breast cancer. A date for the Court of Appeal hearing has not yet been set. Legal fees will be paid with the help of £, in crowdfunding online. It comes after years of battles for around .million women born in the s, who are having their state pension age hiked so it reaches  by this autumn. Ministers say the change is to make womenaposs retirement age equal to menaposs - and would cost £bn to fully reverse. Two women took legal action saying the rises were unlawful age and sex discrimination and came with too little notice. But two judges at the High Court dismissed their claim. The Back to  campaign - which brought the case - says women had a legitimate expectation to receive their pension aged  and demands theof those earned dues. Separately, Women Against State Pension Inequalityis calling for fair transitional arrangements to help women financially, but not a fullto age . Back to  spokeswoman Joanne Welch said: The issue is about pensions but itaposs also about womenaposs rights. The s women have suffered, they experienced all of leaposs inequalities. Why should they carry the City on their backs  Before Octoberaposs ruling, Boris Johnson said he wouldto this issue with fresh vigour and new eyes and see what I can do to sort it out.But during the election campaign he said he would love to magic a solution but it is very expensive to sort out. He added: Iaposm going to be honest with you tonight. I cannot promise that I can magic up that money for you tonight. All the demands the WASPI women have made. It is not possible to satisfy all the demands of the WASPI women. Iaposll put my hands up and confess that. Ms Welch told the Mirror: Boris Johnson promised to look at it with fresh eyes and new vigour. We are holding him to that undertaking and itaposs very important because the court has recognised that we can appeal on all grounds.

title: doting kate middleton shows maternal
story: NewsDoting Kate Middleton shows off maternal side as she vows to change kids livesKate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, has launched a landmark survey on early childhood and is touring the country as she hopes to trigger “lasting change for generations to come”ShareCommentsByRussell MyersBradley JollyOnline journalist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDuchess of Cambridge is pictured interacting with a child at Birmingham science museum " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge is today launching a landmark survey on early childhood which she hopes will trigger “lasting change for generations to come”. Mum-of-three Kate has embarked on a -hour tour of the country, visiting Birmingham, Cardf and Surrey to raise awareness of the poll, Five Big Questions on the Under Fives, thought to be the largest of its kind in the UK. She has been quietly working on the theme since her marriage eight years ago, dedicating the vast majority of her public and private engagements to early years provision. And this afternoon, she showed off her maternal side as she played with young children at a child-sized mini-city at a museum in Birmingham. Heartwarming photos show the -year-old engaging with the youngsters in play as she beams with happiness. She has determined that many of the hardest social challenges facing society can often be traced back to experiences in early childhood and has successfully made the subject her niche. Royal sources said Kate views this as a lelong project with which she hopes to make a tangible dference. Kate said: The Early Years are more crucial for future health and happiness than any other moment in our letime. I want to hear the key issues affecting our families and communities so I can focus my work on where it is needed most. The research was commissioned by the Royal Foundation, which hopes it will spark the biggest ever conversation on early childhood. The Duchess began her whistlestop tour with a visit to MiniBrum, an interactive, child-sized mini-city at Thinktank, Birmingham’s science museum. The Duchess said: What we experience between the ages of  and five shapes the developing brain. They help us avoid adversity, or certainly build resilience to adversity in later le, prevent challenges with mental health later down the line. As a mother, it’s given me a dferent perspective. There’s so much pressure on parents to feel the responsibility is just down to them but actually it’s important to work together as a community. The poll will be online for a month and is designed to recognise that everyone has a role in building the foundations of childhood that have a lelong effect. The results will be revealed in March and will determine the Duchess’s next steps. Kensington Palace said the launch of the survey followed eight years of work by the duchess who firmly believes that experiences in the earliest years – from in the womb to the age of five – are instrumental in shaping future lives. The five questions were compiled after meeting with families across the country and hearing about the issues they deal with day-to-day, reflecting the results of those conversations as well as those with academics, experts, organisations and practitioners. The Duchess will join parents at London Early Years Foundationnursery in Southwark, central London, for the nursery drop off tomorrow, before helping nursery workers serve breakfast to the children, highlighting the importance of nutritious food to a child’s development.

story: NewsHarry Dunn’s grieving parents uncover evidence of  serious crashes by airbasesHarry Dunn died in a crash involving a diplomat’s we - the teens stepfather said nearly all the  similar cases involves a serviceman driving on the wrong side of the roadShareByLouie Smith:,  JAN NewsHarry Dunn " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHarry Dunn’s distraught parents have uncovered evidence of at least  serious crashes involving US personnel on British soil. They say the incidents near US military bases all resulted in either signicant injuries or death. The majority featured US servicemen, servicewomen or their families driving on the wrong side of the road. Last year, the Mirror told how mum Judy Chard, , was lucky to escape with her le when a US soldier ploughed into her just miles from the base where Harry died. The -year-old’s stepfather Bruce Charles has told BBC Breakfast that the list of incidents dates back  years. He said: “I just think it’s shocking that this has been happening for so many years. “Nearly every single one of these cases involves a serviceman driving on the wrong side of the road. “It’s definitely a pattern.”  Bruce, married to Harry’s mum Charlotte, added: “A lot of it doesn’t get reported because there isn’t any dashcam footage of it, so things are mentioned and you hear about them but until you’ve actually seen it on film, you realise it’s happening quite often. “It has to stop. These bases have to realise they have issues with servicemen leaving the bases. “At the moment the bases don’t seem to really want to interact with us and engage with us, so it’s very hard but it is something we’re going to fight and fight for all the way, until we get results.”Motorcyclist Harry died last August after he was involved in a collision with diplomat’s we Anne Sacoolas, . The mum-of-three was allegedly driving on the wrong side of the road near the US intel base RAF Croughton, Northants. She fled Britain claiming diplomatic immunity but is now the subject of extradition proceedings on a death by dangerous driving charge.  In October we revealed the story of a mum who was hospitalised in a crash with an American serviceman two miles from Croughton. Mum-of-four Judy was left with whiplash and injuries to both knees in the  collision. Northamptonshire police Chief Constable Nick Adderley has now pledged to fund driving training for all US staff at Croughton.

story: NewsInside rat-infested flat where dementia patient found dead amid towers of rubbishKoong Boon Khan died shortly after he was found outside his flat in Aigburth, Liverpool in a wheelchair with deep sores across parts of his body and Lewy Body DementiaShareCommentsByJonathan HumphriesMilo Boyd:,  JAN NewsMice and rats infested the flat where Koong Boon Khan was found ill " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dementia-stricken man died with visibly rotten flesh in a squalid, rat infested flat. When police were called to the Aigburth, Liverpool flat of Koong Boon Khan, known as Kenny, his we Lorraine and daughter Juliette, they were so shocked at the conditions they began filming the property.PC Gareth Ward switched on his body-cam and captured around  live mice running around towers of rubbish which almost reached head height, The Liverpool Echo reported. Police attended the home following a  call from Lorraine, , on February , . Lorraine has now been sentenced after initially being charged with manslaughter, which she denied, before pleading guilty to a lesser charge of neglect. Poor Kenny, god love him. Do you know what, he didn’t deserve this. He didn’t, she told the operator after explaining that Kenny wasnapost breathing. Such a lovely, lovely human being and he didn’t … nobody deserves to get dementia. Paramedics arrived and found Kenny, , slumped on a wheelchair outside the flat. Having been blocked from entering the main property by Juliette, the emergency service workers tried in vain to revive the pensioner, who was originally from Malaysia. He was sadly pronounced dead at the scene.  A post-mortem exam found two foul-smelling and very large and very deep pressure sores on his buttocks and lower back, along with several other sores. A pathologist said the sores would have been present for around three months before his death and would have caused him great pain. Gordon Cole QC, prosecuting, told Liverpool Crown Court: Despite the visibly rotting flesh no assistance from health care professionals was sought by his family. The pressure ulceration and infection reached his bones. Other areas of pressure damage followed. In excess of % of Mr Khan’s body surface was damaged.  At the time of his death Kenny had a range of serious health conditions including Lewy Body Dementia, bronchopneumonia, osteoarthritis, emphysema and liver disease. But it was the rancid pressure sores on his body that became infected and led to septicemia, which caused his death. Mr Cole described how PC Ward entered the squalid home. The door to the flat was slightly ajar, he said. PC Ward pushed the door open and immediately noticed an horrendous smell. He looked up the hallway and saw two females, Lorraine Khan and her daughter Juliette Khan.  They were married for more than  years and she found in him, and him in her, both security and love. Mr Power told the court that Lorraine felt overwhelming guilt about how her husband had died. Judge David Aubrey, QC, passing sentence, told her: He was an extremely ill person and you simply didnapost have the capability or wherewithal to care for him, he also being so immobile as a consequence of his illness. You were all living, yourself, your husband and your daughter, in my judgement, in such appalling home conditions, that with respect to you, one would not have thought possible in the st century.

story: NewsLelong vegetarian given McDonalds chicken burger by mistake - and takes biteClancy Bogue, , from Bristol, took a bite out of what she thought was a Vegetable Deluxe burger to find out she had wrongly been given a Chicken Mayo burger insteadShareCommentsByAlexander Brock, Sarah LumleyLorraine King:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsLelong vegetarian Clancy Bogue pictured outside McDonalds " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA teenager who has never eaten meat has not been able to eat properly since after biting into a chicken burger she had mistakenly been given at McDonaldaposs. Clancy Bogue had ordered a Vegetable Deluxe burger at the branch in Cabot Circus, Bristol, when the mix up happened. The -year-old has never eaten meat in her le, having been raised by vegetarians, and has stuck to her meat-free diet for moral reasons. The student, at University of the West of Englandin Bristol, was left feeling sick for days afterwards when she took a bite and realise that she had been given a Chicken Mayo burger instead. The teen said she was distressed when she realised the mistake, and has not been able to eat properly since. And the restaurantaposs manager has apologised for the extremely disappointing incident and claimed an error by a trainee caused the mistake. Describing the moment she inadvertently ate meat for the first time, Ms Bogue said: I ordered my vegetable deluxe meal and took it upstairs to eat. I took a bite and it didnapost seem right. I took a look at it and the inside of the burger was white. I realised then it was chicken and felt really distressed. I had a horrible feeling in my tummy and was almost gagging. I felt like being sick. I went downstairs and said I wanted to speak to the manager, she added. He offered me a refund and a new burger. I didnapost want one and asked how to make a proper complaint.  It was horrible - itaposs thrown me off my eating pattern, she added. I have been feeling quite nauseous. They should have things in place to stop this from happening. I donapost want to eat at any restaurant like that again. In an email to Ms Bogue, the restaurantaposs business manager admitted the mix-up was extremely disappointing. The email read: I have looked in this issue myself and it appears it was a traineeaposs error when finishing the product in the kitchen not being focused on the item at hand. Despite all the procedures in place, such as using a dferent color box and dferent color paper tray liner, the employee failed to fulfil this task to the standard we expect.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrincess Dianaaposs niece is going head to head with the Queenaposs grandson Peter Phillips in promoting a rival milk brand in China.Lady Kitty Spencer is the latest aristocrat with royal connections to trade off her status amid the outrage caused by Prince Harry and Meghan Markle looking to make millions off the aposSussex Royalapos brand.Putting her face to Satine Jersey milk, the daughter of Earl Spencer posed with a cup of tea for photos at the British Museum while Peter has jumped on board with Shanghai-based Bright Dairies.Lady Kitty, , told journalists in China that the Royal Familyaposs day usually begins with a cup of milk or a cup of tea, reports the Mail Online . Satine is sold by Chinese food giant Yili Group. Both first cousins of William and Harry, Lady Kitty and Peteraposs dairy promotion campaigns kicked off in June last year, with products billing themselves as from Jersey cows and targeting the Chinese middle-class market. In her advert, model Lady Kitty is seen sipping tea in the famous museum while a Chinese woman pours milk from a carton titled aposSatine Jersey Milk British Museum Classic Editionapos.  Amongst the promotional material, the company played up her royal connections, despite her not being a member of the Royal Family. She is referred to as the niece of the late Princess Diana and said that she has shared the story of Jersey milk and the British Royal Family. While Lady Kitty herself is quoted as saying: Jersey milk has a close relationship with the British Royal Family. At Buckingham Palace, the official residence of the Queen in London, the Queen’s day begins with drinking a cup of tea.  Jersey milk has been enjoyed by the British Royal Family for many years. Jersey milk is considered to be the finest and most special from the United Kingdom. Lady Kitty grew up in South Africa with mum Victoria and has been based in London for five years, having signed with Storm Management.She posted a photo of herself at the Satine milk launch on Instagram , referring to the deal as a paid partnership with the British Museum.In a behind the scenes video she says she is thrilled...to celebrate the collaboration between the British Museum and Satine.  The Mail reports the museum took a fee for hosting the launch, describing it as commercially sensitive. A spokesman said: The British Museum started its brand licensing programme back in  and has an international programme, with select licensee partners in China, the UK, Europe and North America. The press release details the collaboration on this particular product and the role of the British Museum, whereby the design of the packaging for a specic product was inspired by objects in the British Museum’s collection.  Printed on the milk carton is ‘Satine – The British Museum’ alongside a sketch based on an  lithograph of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert with their children, titled The Royal Children in the Nursery. A copy of the original artwork is in the Royal Collection.Lady Kitty and Peteraposs involvement in lucrative deals comes as  Prince Harry  jetted off to Canada to reunite with we Meghan and son Archie after their decision to step down as senior royals.With their intention of working to become financially independent and having relinquished their titles and promised to repay public funding pumped into  Frogmore Cottage  , they have, however, been criticised over their plans to make millions in endorsements abroad. This includes potential deals with the likes of  Netflix  and Disney.In a behind the scenes interview for his promotions of aposJersey Fresh Milkapos, Peter says he and the other royals were brought up on Jersey milk and says itaposs a privilege to be part of an exciting new project to bring it to China. The -year-old and his sister Zara have never held HRH status and the siblings have been scrutinised before about how they make their money, reports the Mail. A caption for a promotional still of the advert describes Peter as a British Royal Family member while the advert itself features a replica of the coach the Queen uses on state occasions.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A retired soldier says he felt degraded after doctors put him in a nappy and strapped him to a bed in hospital . John Winterburn, , hit his head on a concrete plant pot when he fell during a holiday in Benidorm , Spain.He was rushed to Marina Baixa hospital in Villajoyosa after he started to slur his words. But he and we Dianne, , claim medics there strapped John to a bed and made him wear the nappy for no obvious reason. The pensioner, who served with the Royal Tank Regiment, spent the next  days in hospital before being flown back to Britain for further treatment. Speaking from her home in Leeds, West Yorkshire, today, Dianne said: They put him in a bed nappy and gave him a drug which is only given to psychotic patients. I couldnapost believe it. I was worried he might have a bleed in his brain but scans said he was all clear abut he was going to be put on observation. I thought it would be a day but I was shocked to find him in a dark room strapped to his bed. Heaposs an ex soldier, it was disgusting.  Dianne, who has a son with John, spent the following  days in taxis from Medplaya Hotel Flamingo Oasis in Benidorm. She amassed huge bills on transport and their £, holiday was ruined. She added: His speech was slurred but that was because of the fall. How degrading was this for him  Dianne had to spoon-fed John, who has previously had a heart bypass, and her nightmare only ended when their son Craig Waite flew over. My son Craig is a hero. He flew over from Leeds to save us. I am so grateful, Dianne said.  John, who spent five years in Germany with the British Army, was flown back to Leeds where he was rushed into Leeds General Infirmary before being moved to St James Hospital. He is now recovering at home but is reluctant toto Spain. Iaposm feeling better now that Iaposm home, the dad said. I was out cold for the  days - I was hallucinating that I was back in Germany. Iaposm so happy to be back but itaposs a shame as we love Spain but I donapost think Iaposll be going back there again. I feel sorry for Diane because she deserved to enjoy herself but spent all ten days worrying about me.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA spurned mistress at HSBC referred to a worker her former lover flirted with as p***ybait, a tribunal was told today. Married dad-of-four Robert Clegg, global head of HSBC staff digitisation, was aposon a mission to destroyapos Madeleine Luckham after she ended their extra-marital romance, it was said. Ms Luckham, , a high-flying woman in tech, told the tribunal she suspected her line manager was sleeping with another colleague and that he had sex in the office toilet. But she claimed just before they split in April  she saw Mr Clegg, , get handsy with a SOMO contractor and whispered in her ear weaposd have great sex. Today she was accused of making the derogatory remark.  Jane McCafferty, QC, for the bank and Mr Clegg said: You referred to the woman from SOMO as p***ybait. Madeleine said: No I did not. She confronted him over the remark and they broke up with her telling him please just keep the sleaze out of the office from now on and please keep it away from me, Stratford Employment tribunal heard. She added: It validated everything I felt, not just the rumours, I have seen it with my own eyes. In the context of the rumours, it was not ogling, it was like she was prey.  She added: I was personally upset by the whole thing. He blamed our relationship and the fact it had not been going great. I felt Rob was trying to blame our relationship and his le for what had happened and I was trying to distance myself from this. For me, it was over at this time. At this particular time we were not ing, we had blown up. She is suing Mr Clegg and HSBC for sex discrimination after she was let go and a £,-a-year job said she was promised never materialised. She said she did not enter into an extramarital affair believing she would be the only woman but freaked out when she saw aposthe darker side of thingsapos. She told the tribunal: I did not go into a relationship with a married man thinking I would be the only woman in his le. It was more the darker side of things. The sexual harassment of a colleague, the language that was being used about him, the Weinstein comment. I was freaking out about the whole thing.  Clegg was given the nickname aposWeinsteinapos at the SOMO offices, the tribunal had earlier heard. And she said she felt like a weight had lted after she ended their romance at the Hilton Hotel on April . She told the tribunal: Having just ended the relationship, I felt like a weight had lted. I felt like I could breathe and I was looking forward to moving forward. We were both holding hands and crying during the conversation. It was a break up. But she said everything changed at work following the break up and that Mr Clegg had intimated he was sleeping with somebody  at the office, the tribunal heard. She told the tribunal she suspected this was the woman she had seen him with in the office toilet. She said: I think at this point I was waking up to the person Mr Clegg was. It was a rude awakening, it was a hard awakening. But at the same time, I was flip flopping and feeling sorry for him because of those rumours [the other woman]. I am traumatised.

While the end of the bitterly cold spell is on the horizon, a Public Health England cold weather alert is still in place until am tomorrow, warning that the elderly, very young and people with medical conditions risk getting ill. And the Met Office is warning tonight could see temperatures fall to as low as -C overnight, before things improve tomorrow. This comes after Britain was blanketed in thick freezing fog and frost this morning, which saw cars overturn on icy roads and police issue ice warnings as driving conditions became treacherous. Visibility was as low as under ftand the UK was colder than Reykjavik in Iceland, which reached a low of C today. The lowest temperature recorded overnight was -.C in Oxfordshire. And tonight heading into tomorrow will see aof the below-freezing conditions, with the south and South West of England baring the brunt. Cloud in the far west and northwest will be thick enough for spots of patchy rain. Helen Roberts, a meteorologist with the Met Office , told : There was widespread frost this morning. There will certainly be some frost tonight, but not as much. There will be some fog in the far south of England, with freezing fog confined to south. It will be mostly freezing fog. The minimum temperature last night was -.C in Oxfordshire.Tonight we could see a low temperature -C, across the South West of England. It will be quite a grey start across large parts of the UK tomorrow morning, particularly in England and Wales, with low cloud and hill fog. It wonapost really brighten up for many throughout much of the day. It will feel cold under the cloud cover. But itaposs not all bad news, as the meteorologist said there will be a little brightness around for some. The best chance of brightness will be in the north east of England and eastern Scotland, she said.The maximum temperature we can expect in the far south tomorrow will be C or C, and C or C for much of the west of England.
